content.briefing:
The GPU wars are heating up as NVIDIA dropped Blackwell architecture updates while AMD countered with MI400 details. Both companies are going after the same hyperscaler contracts, and pricing pressure is building. Meanwhile, Microsoft, Google, and AWS all announced regional AI infrastructure expansions this week. The race to reduce inference latency is driving massive capital expenditure across all three cloud giants.

On the semiconductor side, the bottleneck has shifted from raw chip supply to advanced packaging capacity. TSMC demand remains elevated, ASML is shipping more High-NA EUV systems, and Micron is ramping HBM3E production. PayPal blocking $2B in suspicious transactions shows AI-powered fraud detection is no longer optional for payment processors. Palo Alto's $500M acquisition signals cybersecurity M&A is picking up as larger players buy AI capabilities rather than build them in-house.

content.briefing:
Meta officially enters the enterprise AI race with Llama 4 API going live for enterprise customers. This is a direct shot at OpenAI and Anthropic, and Meta's open-weight strategy could undercut pricing across the industry. TSMC's Arizona fab achieved first 3nm wafer production, a significant milestone for US chip sovereignty. While still years behind Taiwan capacity, the momentum is real. Intel 18A entering risk production means their foundry comeback is genuinely in play.

Broadcom's custom AI chip bet is paying off with 50% revenue growth from custom silicon, validating their strategy of building chips for hyperscalers rather than competing with NVIDIA directly. On the security front, CrowdStrike blocking 1M identity attacks daily shows traditional network security is inadequate. Zero trust is now the baseline, not a buzzword. ServiceNow hitting 5M daily AI support requests suggests enterprise AI adoption is past experimentation and into real deployment.

Meta Opens Llama 4 API Access to Enterprise Customers

content.briefing:
CES 2026 made it clear that the AI PC push is real. AMD's Ryzen AI 9, Intel's Core Ultra 300, and Qualcomm's Snapdragon X Elite were all showcased, with every chip vendor betting big on on-device AI. The question isn't whether AI PCs will happen, but who captures the enterprise refresh cycle. TSMC announced a $20B US investment commitment, serious money that hedges against Taiwan geopolitical risk while locking in CHIPS Act subsidies.

Affirm's 45% holiday volume surge shows buy-now-pay-later isn't dead despite rising rates, with consumer credit appetite remaining strong. Mastercard's Crypto Credential going live in 10 countries suggests traditional finance is done fighting crypto and is now moving to capture the rails. Edge AI is emerging as the next battleground with Cloudflare processing 10B daily AI requests and Zscaler adding AI to Zero Trust. Marvell's custom silicon revenue doubling year-over-year confirms hyperscalers are diversifying beyond NVIDIA.

content.briefing:
Q4 2025 earnings season kicks off next week with consensus expecting strong AI-related revenue. Watch for margin compression as cloud providers continue ramping spending. The market is pricing in perfection, so any miss will hurt. AWS Bedrock adding Claude 3.5 Opus shows Anthropic models are getting deeper integration, and the AI model market is consolidating around a few major platforms where distribution through hyperscalers is becoming critical.

ASML's guidance beat is significant because when the company that makes the machines that make the chips says demand is stronger than expected, the semiconductor capex cycle has legs. TSMC's CoWoS advanced packaging capacity tripling is the real story since everyone has chips but not everyone can package them for AI workloads. This bottleneck won't ease until late 2026. SoFi hitting $25B in deposits shows digital-first banking is taking real share from incumbents. Synopsys claiming 40% design time reduction with AI-driven EDA tools could accelerate chip development cycles if it holds up in production.

content.briefing:
Microsoft getting early GPT-5 access on Azure underscores the depth of their OpenAI partnership and puts pressure on Google and Anthropic to respond. The frontier model race is intensifying and enterprise customers are watching closely. Google DeepMind continues pushing boundaries on multimodal AI research, and the gap between research breakthroughs and production deployment is shrinking, which benefits Google Cloud's competitive position.

TSMC 2nm staying on track for 2026 production is critical since Apple, NVIDIA, and AMD are all counting on this node for 2027 products. Memory is no longer a commodity business as Micron's GDDR7 mass production and HBM4 development show. AI workloads require specialized memory, benefiting Micron, Samsung, and SK Hynix. Intuit gearing up TurboTax AI features for tax season could be a leading indicator of consumer AI adoption. Block's Bitcoin holdings hitting $1B market value is notable since crypto rallies give them asymmetric upside that pure fintech plays don't offer.

content.briefing:
The supply and demand imbalance for AI chips persists. Grace Hopper shipments to hyperscalers, MI350X benchmarks showing performance gains, and ASML's record backlog all point to the same conclusion: AI chip demand isn't slowing. Anyone betting on a peak AI narrative is early at best. Custom silicon is gaining ground as Google's Axion now powers 20% of GCP workloads and AWS Graviton4 expands to all major regions. Hyperscalers are serious about reducing NVIDIA dependence.

TSMC's Japan fab starting volume production adds geographic diversification to their manufacturing base, giving Sony and other Japanese customers better access while marginally decreasing Taiwan concentration risk. PayPal's PYUSD stablecoin hitting $2B market cap faster than expected suggests enterprise use cases are materializing, with cross-border payments and B2B settlement as the killer apps. Palo Alto's Unit 42 threat report shows attack sophistication increasing, meaning the cybersecurity spending cycle is far from over. Intel Foundry winning a major automotive client could be the first crack in TSMC's dominance for that segment.

content.briefing:
2026 starts strong with analysts raising price targets across semiconductors and cloud after holiday data came in solid. The AI infrastructure buildout narrative remains intact, though valuations are stretched. Microsoft opening Copilot Studio to enterprises could accelerate AI adoption beyond IT departments, with business users building their own AI workflows becoming the next phase. NVIDIA AI Enterprise 5.0 adding production MLOps features signals their push beyond hardware into software to capture more of the AI value chain.

Coinbase's Base network hitting 10M daily transactions shows their Layer 2 play is gaining real traction. Lower fees and faster settlement could make crypto more practical for everyday use. ASML investing 1 billion euros in pellicle production is notable since this obscure but critical component has been a bottleneck and ASML solving it themselves rather than waiting for suppliers shows urgency. Adobe Firefly enterprise API adoption tripling suggests generative AI for creative work is past experimentation, and marketing budgets are actively shifting toward AI tools.
